captions.text:
House training your puppy
requires more than a stack of
old newspapers.

It calls for patience,
commitment, and above all,
consistency.

Hi, I'm Kathy Santo for
Iams with Howdini.

And today we're going
to talk about how to
house train your puppy.

A trusting and consistent
relationship is fundamental to
successful house training.

The more consistent you
are, the faster
your puppy will learn.

House training a puppy can
take several weeks and

sometimes longer with
smaller breeds.

The first step to house training
your puppy is to
establish a routine.

Puppies did best on a regular
schedule, because it teaches

them that there are times
to eat, times to play,
and times to potty.

As a general rule, a puppy can
control his bladder about an
hour for every month of age.

So if your puppy is only three
months old, he can probably

only hold it for about three
hours, if not less.

Make sure to take him right out
after he wakes up, during

and after play time, and after
eating or drinking, because

these are times he's most
likely to have to go.

If you work and are unable to
take your puppy outside as

often as needed, you could hire
a dog walker to give your
puppy his necessary breaks.

I recommend picking a specific
bathroom spot outside and

always taking him there first
when he's on a leash.

While your puppy is going, say
something like "go potty" so

that you can eventually
use that phrase to
remind him what to do.

You should take him out for a
walk or play time after he's

gone potty, or he might
just learn to hold
it to keep you outside.

Reward your puppy every time
he goes potty outdoors with

praise or a treat, but make
sure to do so immediately

before he goes back
into the house.

Rewarding correct behavior
is the best way
to teach your puppy.

Be careful not to reward your
puppy until he's completely

finished, or he may forget to
finish up outside and then
have an accident inside.

And remember, what goes into a
puppy on a schedule comes out
of a puppy on a schedule.

So always take your puppy
out after feeding.

Try picking up your puppy's
water dish about two and a

half hours before bedtime, so he
won't have as much water to
try and hold overnight.

If you keep a consistent
schedule, your puppy could be

house trained by the time he's
five to six months old.

But don't be discouraged if it
takes your puppy longer or has
an occasional accident.

Many factors, including breed
of dog, consistency, and

temperament, can contribute to
a longer training period.

If you feel that there's little
to no progress, consult

with your veterinarian to be
sure that a medical issue,

such as a bladder infection,
isn't the culprit.

Supervision in the beginning
is critical.

Exercise pens are extremely
helpful while house training.

Keeping your puppy in a small
space within eyesight will

allow you to notice and react
when they start showing the
signs of needing to eliminate.

Those signs can be barking,
scratching at the door,

squatting, sniffing,
or circling.

If you're unable to monitor your
puppy, you can confine

him to an area small enough
so that he won't want to
eliminate there.

A space just large enough for
him to lay down with a couple
extra inches is just fine.

Many people choose to combine
with a crate which can be very

helpful for house training
your young dog.

For more information on crate
training watch "How to crate
train your puppy."

I'm Kathy Santo for Iams with
Howdini, and I hope that

you've found this helpful as you
welcome your new addition
to your family.

For more information on puppy
care and training, visit
iams.com/puppy.

comments.text:
Hi,
We've got a 10 week old German shepherd pup who is refusing to go toilet 
outside. She will end up holding it in, no matter how long we are outside, 
then going toilet as soon as we go back inside. She will even hold it in so 
long that she gets agitated, and clearly wants to go, but refuses to. When 
she gets agitated we will usually give in and let her in.

How can we encourage her to go outside rather than in? At the moment she 
doesn't go outside at all so can't treat or reward her when going outside 
to teach her that this is the right behaviour.

Thanks﻿
comments.author: TuonoV

comments.text:
+TuonoV Couple of questions...how often are you taking her out?  At 10 
weeks it needs to be every 2-3 hours.  Do you potty her on leash?  Don't 
just let her walk around the yard.  Take her to the spots you want her to 
go.  

And, no matter what, NEVER scold her for peeing in the house.  If you do 
that, she will fear pottying in your presence.  Another thing you can try 
is taking the potty pad outside (if you use them at all).  When she goes 
outside...treat and praise like she's won the nobel peace prize!

You can also put her back in the crate for 5 mins if she doesn't go outside 
and then take her out again.  By letting her come in, you are reinforcing 
the behavior of potty inside.
comments.author: Karen Levy

comments.text:
+Carrot teeman The dog I am thinking of fostering is a pit bull mix. She is 
4 months old. I already know that she is very attentive and could be very 
easy to train. The first time I met her, I taught her "come". My dog loves 
puppies but I am going to make sure they like each other in neutral 
territory before bringing her into my house.
comments.author: Chrissy Irwin

comments.text:
He's a mutt. Only speculation can tell. I got him when he was just 9 weeks 
old. The rescue (not the one I volunteer at now) said he was a Yellow 
Lab/Wire Haired Terrier mix but I very highly doubt that. They didn't know 
his background because he was found as a stray the same week I adopted him. 
To me, and this is just speculation, he could be boxer, shepherd and/or lab 
mix. Don't know where they got the small-breed terrier from. He is about 65 
pounds so smaller than the average shepherd. He is high energy.
comments.author: Chrissy Irwin

comments.text:
+Chrissy Irwin
I thought you were saying I wasn't a good owner,seeing how you say you were 
not saying that then so be it.I walk my dog that much because he is a 5 
month old shepard & has alot of energy & I also enjoy the excercise.I also 
give him a full one days rest because he is a shepard & they have a history 
of hip displasia so rest is important as well.Alot of dogs don't need that 
kind of excercise.What kind of dog do you own?
comments.author: Carrot teeman

comments.text:
+Carrot teeman I'm not debating on whether or not you are a good owner. I 
didn't imply that I have expertise. I do walk my dog 2 times a day and my 
mother or sister will give him a short walk at some point in the day. I 
take very good care of him in training, playing, grooming, socializing, 
etc. I also regularly volunteer at a dog rescue and have worked on training 
dogs there, although the inconsistency of having a bunch of different 
walkers at once makes the process more difficult. I also trained my 
neighbors dog and walk him with mine. They rarely seemed to walk their dog 
and didn't want me to take him because he is a strong puller but I worked 
on it with him and now he's fine. I'm only watching this video to get a 
refresher on potty training because while my shelter is moving they need 
fosters and I figured I would work with the pup when I foster her. So I 
guess that is my "expertise" although when you say that I assume you mean 
professional which I have none of. BTW when I make lengthy responses or 
disagree with someone on the internet people get a different tone than I am 
implying so just so you know I am not being aggressive or anything lol.
comments.author: Chrissy Irwin

comments.text:
+Chrissy Irwin
I do that for my dog 6 days a week & like god he rest on the 7th & thinks 
its the end of the world on that day,haha.
comments.author: Carrot teeman

Please give me your expertise?How did we train your dog to potty in the

hugs,kisses & talk.

animals for the movies & everything he has said has worked for me & I will

i had many puppies down through the years... they should not be indoors.... 
even as puppies... get them a comfortable dog box.... treat them by leaving 
them indoors for short periods of time... same with cats... leave them out 
to the freedom they deserve... then when they come in they will never poo 
or pee in your home... never keep animals cooped up in your home. its 
unhealthy... i have a cat... hes 9 years old... out all the time.... had 
dog many years ago ... lived till 11 years old... just google cats and dogs 
and lifespan ... ﻿

comments.text:
I have a miniature poodle, and he's a very smart pup. I trained him within 
one week. I had to stay consistent and I never lost sight of him, I got his 
crate to be the exact size of him so he won't soil it, and I bring him to 
the same spot after every meal, nap, or when I saw him sniffing. He's only 
9 weeks, but you must be consistent and stern and also dedicated. I wake up 
at 6:45am each morning to take him out. I take up his water at 6:30 after 
his last meal. Prevents potty accidents at night. This is my first dog lol, 
only a teen ﻿

comments.text:
i have a pug and i live in an apartment,he is 8 months old he always pee 
near my couch, he is so stubborn what should i do?
and his eating timings are inconsistent ﻿
comments.author: FUS RO DAH

comments.text:
Well FUS RO DAH the reason your pug keeps pooping near your couch is 
because dogs poop/pee in one spot or near that spot and since he's 
pooped/peed there, he keeps pooping there. If you want him to stop, try to 
get him to pee/poop on like a potty pallet and try as hard as you can to 
get rid of the smell (the areas he has pooped/peed at) and once you've got 
him to pee on the pallet, have him use the pallet a few more times (use 3 
about for he doesnt miss) and then take the pallet outside and place it 
where you want him to always pee near. I hope this works, if it doesnt, msg 
me :D
comments.author: MrRichHobo 13

comments.text: Put a potty pad beside your coush on the side he pees on!

comments.text:
i train my puppy to do potty and pee outside the house in two days. he 
normally wake up at 7 :00 i took him outside and waited until he potty and 
pee i did the same for two more days and know he goes outside to do hid 
needs every morning!﻿
comments.author: Hayate Nakamura

comments.text:
Me too. I got my german shepherd/lab mix puppy when he was 6 weeks old. I 
took him outside about every 1 1/2 to 2 hours and after the second day he 
began to go to the door when he needed to pee or poo. I gave him a treat 
when he pooed and showed him how to scratch at the door. I had newspaper at 
the door for a couple of weeks in case I couldn't get there in time but 
still had only one or two pee accidents and he's never pooed in the house. 
Don't know what she's talking about it taking weeks to train. All it takes 
is consistency and patience on the part of the owner.

comments.author: Brandy Cook

comments.text:
This worked for my dog, whenever he/she pees in the house put his/her nose 
in the pee and tap it's little bum. Than take him/her out right away even 
though he already went, he/she will realize that the pee is supposed to go 
outside not inside. And when he's outside watch him/her and get excited and 
talk all happy when he/she goes potty outside, and he/she will realize you 
like it when he/she goes outside. Not inside. A lot of websites and videos 
say there's no need for this but I tried all their tips and this was the 
only one that worked. Show your pup that your the boss, not him/her and 
he/she can't do whatever he/she wants. It's not animal abuse, they don't 
get hurt.
comments.author: Julia  Borcoman
